The pathogens implicated in food-borne infections cover a wide spectrum of microbes including bacteria, parasites, viruses, and fungi.

- 15 Some of the common food-borne pathogens and types of food they affect are shown in Table 1. The incidence/prevalence of food-borne diseases caused by different pathogens has changed in the last few decades. For example, in the United Kingdom, in 2010, Campylobacter displaced Salmonella as the prime cause of food-borne disease while the incidence of Listeria monocytogenes rose between 2001 and 2009.
16 Viruses are implicated in an increasing number of food-borne cases in the United Kingdom currently, while toxin-producing Escherichia coli such as E coli 0157:H7 remain less common, but serious pathogens due to their clinical impact.
16 In the next decades of years, new food-borne pathogens are likely to emerge globally driven by factors such as microbial evolution and changes in food production processes.
17 - 19 In addition, food-borne infections due to existing pathogens can be expected to increase, especially in developing countries, partly because of environmental and demographic changes, as well as massive consumption of risky foods.
